title: How to Check Your Kitchen Herbs for Freshness

steps.headline: Inspect the bottle.
steps.description: Is it covered with lots of dust? That's a bad first sign.

steps.headline: Try to open the bottle.
steps.description: Is the lid stuck? Throw it away now and don't even go on.

steps.headline: Open the lid and look at the herbs.
steps.description: Do they appear dusty, pale instead of green, or clumped with some sticky stuff (spider webs)? If so, throw them out.

steps.headline: Look at the herbs again.
steps.description: Do they move a bit? Are they infested with tiny insects? Definitely throw them out.

steps.headline: Smell the herbs.
steps.description: Do you smell simply old bottle or dust when you put your nose close to the opening? Throw them away!

steps.headline: Shake the bottle gently.
steps.description: Does dust seem to fly up at you? Do you see any funny looking foreign substance in them? Don't even look further. Throw them away.

steps.headline: Pour some of the herb onto a clean napkin, paper towel, or white plate.
steps.description: Take a pinch in your fingers and crush it. Smell it. Do you smell some definite herb? If you still don't see or smell anything that shouldn't be there, such as insects, and if the herb looks like bits of leaf (instead of dust), then it's probably all right  . Try it but then be sure to buy more the next time you're shopping if you still question its freshness.

Pour some of the herb onto a clean napkin, paper towel, or white plate. Take a pinch in your fingers and crush it. Smell it. Do you smell some definite herb? If you still don't see or smell anything that shouldn't be there, such as insects, and if the herb looks like bits of leaf (instead of dust), then it's probably all right  .
